  • 泽伦斯基预计将于周六晚上抵达
  • G7成员同意加强对俄制裁
  • G7希望稳定和建设性的中国关系草案

世界上最富有的民主国家的领导人周五同意加强对俄罗斯的制裁，而在日本广岛市会谈后将发布的公报草案强调有必要减少对与中国的贸易依赖。

七国集团 (G7) 领导人将于本周末加入乌克兰总统沃洛德米尔·泽连斯基 (Volodymyr Zelenskiy)，誓言限制对俄罗斯的任何出口，以帮助其在与乌克兰的 15 个月战争中发挥作用。

“这包括俄罗斯用来重建其战争机器的工业机械、工具和其他技术的出口，”他们在周五发布的一份联合声明中表示，并补充说他们将采取措施限制俄罗斯从金属和钻石贸易中获得的收入。

路透社看到的最终公报初稿称，在 G7 国家越来越多地认为中国对经济安全构成威胁的问题上，他们同意中国作为世界第二大经济体的地位意味着除了寻求合作别无选择.

“我们的政策方针不是为了伤害中国，我们不寻求阻碍中国的经济进步和发展，”该草案称，该草案仍有待修改。

尽管如此，该草案继续敦促采取措施“减少关键供应链中的过度依赖”，并打击技术转让和数据披露中的“恶意行为”。

它还重申台湾海峡和平与稳定的必要性，并敦促中国敦促俄罗斯停止对乌克兰的军事侵略。

G7 的成员——美国、日本、德国、英国、法国、加拿大和意大利——将利用为期 3 天的会议就没有缓和迹象的乌克兰冲突讨论战略。

在日本众议院代表广岛的日本首相岸田文雄说，他选择这座城市举行峰会是为了将注意力集中在军备控制上。

广岛和另一个日本城市长崎在 78 年前被美国的核袭击摧毁，结束了第二次世界大战。

规避

在第二次世界大战后成为世界上最富有的国家后，G7 民主国家越来越受到崛起的中国和不可预测的俄罗斯的挑战。

有证据表明现有的俄罗斯制裁因规避而被削弱，他们表示该集团正在与任何受限制的 G7 商品、服务或技术可以通过这些国家转运到俄罗斯的国家“接触”。

“我们注意到并鼓励这些国家做出承诺，以确保我们的措施不被规避并产生预期效果，”他们说，但没有点名任何领土。

德国贸易数据的细目显示，其对俄罗斯周边国家的出口大幅增长，引发了人们对这些邻国商品再出口的担忧。

G7 国家重申谴责俄罗斯的侵略行为，并承诺在今明两年向乌克兰提供军事援助和经济援助方面进一步支持乌克兰饱受战争蹂躏的经济。

两名参与 G7 峰会的官员表示，泽伦斯基将于周日出席。由于问题的敏感性，他们拒绝透露姓名。

  • 阿萨德重返阿拉伯阵营
  • 叙利亚领导人因镇压、战争而被排斥
  • 美国反对政策转变
  • 乌克兰的泽伦斯基访问峰会

叙利亚总统巴沙尔·阿萨德周五在阿拉伯峰会上受到热烈欢迎，在多年来一直避开他的领导人会议上赢得沙特阿拉伯王储的拥抱，这是美国和其他西方大国反对的政策转变.

阿萨德在俄罗斯的帮助下扭转了叙利亚内战的局势，因此长期受到阿拉伯国家的排斥，乌克兰总统沃洛德米尔·泽伦斯基 (Volodymyr Zelenskiy) 也将加入峰会，他希望为基辅与俄罗斯入侵者的战斗争取支持。

海湾国家试图在乌克兰冲突中保持中立，尽管西方向海湾产油国施加压力，要求其帮助孤立同为 OPEC+ 成员的俄罗斯。

叙利亚重新加入阿拉伯联盟是一个强烈的信号，表明阿萨德十多年的孤立正在结束。

在叙利亚被禁赛 12 年后，沙特王储穆罕默德·本·萨勒曼在吉达与阿萨德握手。在会议开始之前，王储在正式合影前拥抱了阿萨德。

曾经深受美国影响的石油大国沙特阿拉伯在过去一年中在阿拉伯世界发挥了外交带头作用，与伊朗重建关系，欢迎叙利亚回归，并调解苏丹冲突。

“美国人感到沮丧。我们（海湾国家）是生活在这个地区的人，我们正试图用我们手中可用的工具尽可能多地解决我们的问题，”一位接近政府圈子的海湾消息人士说.

一个高度敏感的问题是阿萨德与伊朗人的密切关系，这让阿拉伯国家感到不安。

一位海湾分析人士告诉路透社，叙利亚有成为伊朗附属国的风险，并问道：“我们是希望叙利亚少一点阿拉伯色彩，多一点伊朗色彩，还是……回到阿拉伯阵营？”

在欢迎阿萨德回来后，阿拉伯国家希望他控制叙利亚蓬勃发展的毒品贸易，以换取更紧密的联系。

随着数百万逃离叙利亚的难民返回家园，芬乃他林贸易已成为阿拉伯领导人的一大担忧，就像他们对什叶派伊斯兰主义伊朗在阿拉伯国家建立立足点的担忧一样。

战争摧毁了叙利亚曾经富有成效的经济，摧毁了基础设施、城市和工厂，而阿萨德无疑将从海湾投资中获益。

在中国于 3 月谈判达成协议后，阿拉伯与阿萨德的和解势头增强，利雅得与伊朗恢复外交关系，伊朗与俄罗斯的关系帮助阿萨德击败逊尼派叛军并重新控制了一些主要城市。

然而，叙利亚的大片地区仍处于土耳其支持的叛乱分子和激进伊斯兰组织以及美国支持的库尔德民兵的控制之下。

为这场长达 12 年的冲突寻找政治解决方案仍然是阿拉伯和西方国家面临的一大难题。

据联合国难民署称，自 2011 年以来，已有超过 1400 万叙利亚人被迫逃离家园。大约 680 万叙利亚人仍然在自己的国家境内流离失所，其中 90% 的人口生活在贫困线以下。

超过 350,000 人被杀。约有550万叙利亚难民生活在叙利亚的五个邻国——土耳其、黎巴嫩、约旦、伊拉克和埃及。

化学武器

预计阿萨德将于周五晚些时候在峰会上发表讲话，这是一次引人注目的外交调整。十年前，在卡塔尔主办的一次阿拉伯峰会上，叙利亚反对派坐在叙利亚席位上。 2018 年，卡塔尔埃米尔表示，该地区不能容忍像阿萨德这样的“战争罪犯”。

在峰会之前，美国重申反对与大马士革关系正常化。

美国国务院副发言人韦丹特帕特尔在华盛顿对记者说：“我们不认为应该（允许）叙利亚重新加入阿拉伯联盟，”并补充称不应取消制裁。

但帕特尔补充说，“我们有许多共同目标”，例如将 2012 年在叙利亚被绑架的前美国海军陆战队记者奥斯汀·泰斯带回家。

美国两党立法者团体上周提出了一项法案，旨在禁止美国承认阿萨德为叙利亚总统，并增强华盛顿实施制裁的能力。

时任美国总统唐纳德·特朗普在 2018 年将一只使用化学武器的“动物”称为“动物”——他一直否认使用过这种武器。战争开始后，阿萨德很少离开叙利亚，只去了伊朗和俄罗斯，直到 2022 年他访问了阿拉伯联合酋长国——这是他自 2011 年以来首次访问阿拉伯国家。

叙利亚的大片地区仍不在他的控制范围内。

土耳其军队部署在西北部的大部分地区，该地区仍处于叛军手中，而库尔德人领导的团体在部署在那里的美军的支持下控制着东部和东北部，包括叙利亚的油田。

叙利亚政治反对派阿萨德的知名人物塞勒姆·梅斯利特 (Salem Al-Meslit) 在推特上写道，他的出席是“对战犯的免费奖励”。

阿萨德重返阿拉伯阵营是中东更广泛趋势的一部分，中东的对手一直在采取措施修复因多年冲突和竞争而紧张的关系。

Simon Lewis 在华盛顿的补充报道； Michael Georgy 撰写； Simon Cameron-Moore 和 Alex Richardson 编辑; Fri, 19 May 2023 11:53:09 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/syrias-assad-attend-arab-summit-bringing-regional-isolation-an-end-2023-05-19/ https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/syrias-assad-attend-arab-summit-bringing-regional-isolation-an-end-2023-05-19/Aziz Yaakoubi, Samia Nakhoul沙特阿拉伯阿拉伯/峰会（更新 6，PIX，电视） Exclusive: Staff at top U.S. farm research center file complaint alleging unsafe work conditions

据路透社查阅的文件和采访显示，美国最大的农业研究机构的三名员工向联邦举报人投诉称，尽管农民正面临气候变化等紧迫问题，但该机构的条件对工人有害并破坏了他们的研究。职员。

位于华盛顿特区附近的贝尔茨维尔农业研究中心（BARC）是美国农业部（USDA）拥有的最大的研究机构，长期以来一直是美国农业研究的旗舰。然而，根据文件和采访，由于裁员和延期维护导致其基本系统年久失修，该设施的状况多年来一直在恶化。

路透社采访了该设施的五名现任员工和一名前任员工，他们表示实验室的通风橱不符合规范，火警警报器坏了几个月，剧烈的温度波动使工作变得不舒服并破坏了实验，甚至连厕所和自来水都无法使用。经常不工作。该新闻机构审查了员工分享的数百份文件、照片和视频，以支持他们的说法。

周二向保护联邦举报人的美国特别顾问办公室 (OSC) 提交的员工申诉在一份档案中列举了多年的管理不善和不安全的工作条件，其详细信息此前并未公开。

美国政府雇员联合会 (AFGE) 助理总法律顾问 Ward Morrow 表示，OSC 正在安排与提出投诉的员工面谈。

“我们员工的健康和福祉是我们的首要任务，”负责监管 BARC 的美国农业部农业研究局 (ARS) 的一位发言人告诉路透社，“我们仍然致力于不断努力使我们的研究设施现代化，以便他们拥有工作空间这可以支持他们进行的关键研究。”

代表 BARC 工人的 AFGE Local 3147 副总裁兼该设施的生物科学实验室技术员 Asaki “Teddi” Mitchell 表示，核心问题是管理层的“常态化冷漠”。

在 BARC 工作了 34 年并且是提出投诉的工作人员之一的米切尔称该设施的状况“令人心碎”。

“我们可以在这里做很多事情，”她谈到对气候变化和粮食安全等紧迫农业问题的研究时说。 “我们只是不这样做。”

员工多年的抱怨在 2022 年圣诞节达到了顶峰，当时一阵寒冷的天气炸裂了 BARC 研究大楼内的管道。水、天花板瓷砖和石膏板层叠流入办公室、实验室和储藏室，破坏设备、记录和数据。

12 月的洪水过后，美国农业部的管理人员要求员工返回大楼开始清理过程，尽管该空间 - 研究害虫、入侵物种和水资源的实验室 - 仍然散落着碎片，独立测试显示这些碎片含有石棉和霉菌，根据内部电子邮件和来自外部承包商的报告。

ARS 发言人表示，该机构已承诺提供 925,000 美元用于修复被水淹没的建筑物和更换损坏的设备，并进行了霉菌修复。

BARC 的问题说明了美国公共农业研究的衰退状况，专家称这威胁到该国作为领先农业创新者的地位，即使农民面临着气候变化带来的前所未有的挑战。美国农业部发言人证实，资金减少正在影响科学研究。

历史上，政府拥有和资助的实验室通过开发高产和抗虫害作物和动物，帮助美国成为领先的农业经济体。但根据美国农业部的数据，过去 20 年公共研究支出下降了三分之一，尽管中国、欧盟和巴西的支出有所增加。

美国的大多数农业研究已转移到私营部门，农民主要通过从公司购买产品来获得其创新成果。

农业部长汤姆维尔萨克在 3 月份谈到这一趋势的后果时对国会说：“我们必须明白这会产生相关成本，农民最终会承担该成本。”

明尼苏达大学应用经济学教授 Phil Pardey 说，公共研究也倾向于强调社会价值问题，例如气候变化。他说，如果没有更多的公共研究，美国农民对不断变化的农场条件的适应力可能会降低，并进一步落后于国际竞争对手。

裁员

BARC 工厂成立于 1910 年，占地近 7,000 英亩，位于美国首都附近的马里兰州乔治王子县。 The property is dotted with stately brick laboratory and administrative buildings and dozens of greenhouses, livestock barns and research fields.

The issues documented by workers and reported here affect primarily the research buildings on the campus, whose labs conduct experiments on invasive insects, animal genomics, sustainable crop practices and more.

BARC churned out important findings for decades. Its researchers bred the turkey most Americans eat on Thanksgiving in the 1940s and the Roma tomato in the 1950s.

But today, staff cuts and vacancies are hindering research scientists and their staff.

The number of employees at BARC has fallen from 600 in 2017 to 550 today, according to an ARS spokesperson. The facilities staff has shrunk from 121 in 2012 to 87 in 2023, and as of May, the facilities department had 30 vacancies, the spokesperson said.

At eight BARC buildings, the fire alarm systems are inoperable, according to documentation provided by the workers. To compensate, staff have been asked to conduct a fire watch, in which monitors patrol an area and alert others to any sign of fires, according to internal staff advisories from management seen by Reuters.

Temperature regulation is another issue. One recent spring day, an employee's office reached 93 degrees, they told Reuters. On December 26, 2022, the day after the major flood, it was 47 degrees inside that building, and staff had been using space heaters for offices and labs, according to photos taken on the 26th and seen by Reuters.

The unreliable conditions are affecting research outcomes, making it at times impossible to complete experiments or replicate their findings, said two research employees.

Claudette Joyner, president of AFGE Local 3147 and a realty specialist at BARC who has worked there for 37 years, said ongoing vacancies raise existential questions.

“I can't leave this place for the next generation to worry about basic needs,” said Joyner, who is another of the staff who filed complaints. “That's where it's at: can we perform the basic job here at the facility?”

The ARS spokesperson told Reuters that “declining investment in agricultural research means that we are missing critical opportunities to capitalize on the powerful potential of our world-class scientists.”

'WE'RE EXPOSED'

The deficiencies at BARC also pose significant health risks, employees say.

At the building that flooded in December, the laboratory chemical fume hoods, which are meant to ventilate research areas, are nearly all out of compliance with USDA code, according to data from annual inspections in 2020, 2021, and 2022 collated by BARC staff and seen by Reuters.

Hoods must draw air at an average of 60 to 100 feet per minute, a measurement called the “face velocity,” to ensure proper ventilation, according to USDA standards.

All but one of the 28 fume hoods in the BARC building had face velocities outside the recommended range at some point in the three years, with 18 hoods out of compliance for all three years, according to the data.

This spring, Mitchell was overwhelmed by an unidentified chemical smell at the building, fainted, and hit her head, requiring emergency medical services, according to her account and documents seen by Reuters. Since the incident, she has had increased headaches and is still not sure what caused it.

“Employees are exposed to chemicals, biologicals, fumes, construction hazards, physical hazards - we're exposed to a number of things at a facility this big,” Mitchell said.

The USDA did not comment on specific allegations of health risks.

After the December flood, a firm brought in by USDA to assess the damage, Environmental Health Consultants LLC, found asbestos in flooring and ceiling material that had fallen into offices and labs, and mold in some areas of the building, according to reports prepared on January 3 and 4 by the firm for USDA and seen by Reuters.

After receiving the reports and a contractor's cleanup quote, BARC's director, Howard Zhang, told employees in a January 9 email seen by Reuters to enter the building to retrieve items they wanted to save to lower the cleanup cost. While the mold report included a recommendation that cleanup workers wear respirators and full-body coveralls, Zhang's email only recommended that staff wear masks.

Zhang did not respond to a request to comment and USDA did not provide any comment on the timeline or conditions of workers returning to the flooded building. The ARS spokesperson told Reuters weekly mold air sampling is ongoing in the building.

USDA management has been made aware of these issues. On February 22, several BARC employees met with Thomas Shanower, the director of USDA's Northeast Area, a division that oversees 15 research centers, including BARC. They showed him a slideshow, seen by Reuters, that documented building and safety issues.

Conditions at the facility have not changed since the meeting, said Mitchell, who attended.

The issues with chemical fumes, fire protection and other conditions could violate Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) standards, said Milly Rodriguez, health and safety specialist with the AFGE.

“Some of those could have longer-term health effects,” Rodriguez said.

Employees at BARC have also not received mandatory OSHA training in several years, according to the slideshow prepared by staff for the February meeting with BARC management.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy landed in Jeddah on Friday to attend an Arab League summit , where Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, heavily-backed by Russia in his country's civil war, will also be present now that his regional isolation ended.

Zelenskiy arrived on a French government plane. He is also due to attend the G7 leaders' summit in the Japanese city of Hiroshima this weekend.

"Kingdom of Saudi Arabia plays a significant role and we are ready to take our cooperation to a new level," he tweeted shortly after arrival.

Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman has mediated in the Russia-Ukraine conflict before.

Last year Prince Mohammed won a diplomatic triumph when he secured the release of 10 foreigners captured by Russia in Ukraine. The move was apparently made possible by his close ties with Russian President Vladimir Putin.

Gulf states have tried to remain neutral in the Ukraine conflict despite Western pressure on Gulf oil producers to help isolate Russia, a fellow OPEC+ member.

The kingdom faced heavy criticism from the United States over an OPEC+ decision to cut oil production, seen as helping Russia to refill its coffers by boosting prices.

Even though the October decision initially drew heavy criticism from the United States and other Western countries, market dynamics since then have shown the cuts to be prudent.

At a time when Russia's war on the Ukraine has roiled global energy markets, the role the kingdom plays as the world's largest oil exporter has grown in importance to both Washington and Moscow.

Reporting by Clauda Tanios and Jana Choukeir; Editing by Hugh Lawson ; Fri, 19 May 2023 10:31:41 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/ukraines-zelenskiy-lands-jeddah-attend-arab-league-al-hadath-tv-2023-05-19/ https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/ukraines-zelenskiy-lands-jeddah-attend-arab-league-al-hadath-tv-2023-05-19/Reuters SAUDI ARABS/SUMMIT UKRAINE (UPDATE 2, PIX) India regulator 'draws a blank' in foreign links probe into Adani, shares rise

India's markets watchdog has "drawn a blank" in investigations into suspected violations in overseas investments in the Adani group and pursuing the case could be a "journey without a destination", a court-appointed panel said.

Shares of companies of the coal-to-airports conglomerate, controlled by billionaire Gautam Adani, were up between 1.2% to 7% in late trade on Friday in a largely flat wider market.

The group's listed companies lost more than $100 billion in market value earlier this year after US-based Hindenburg Research raised several governance concerns. The group has denied wrongdoing.

Following this, the Supreme Court asked the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) to probe some of the allegations made and submit its findings to a six-member panel formed in March, which included a retired judge and veteran bankers.

"The foundation of SEBI's suspicion that led to investigations into the overseas entities' ownership is that they have 'opaque' structures," said the panel in a report dated May 6 and seen by Reuters on Friday.

"The ultimate chain of ownership above the 13 overseas entities is not clear."

But despite involving various Indian and overseas agencies in the investigation across multiple countries, "SEBI has drawn a blank", the report said, adding that trying to prove who had invested in foreign portfolio investors who then pumped money into Adani could be an arduous task.

"It is evident that such an exercise could be a voluminous one but potentially a journey without a destination," the panel said. " ... it would be a humongous task to figure out who the ultimate beneficial owner is."

Adani and the SEBI did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

The court on Wednesday granted SEBI additional time until Aug. 14 to complete its investigation into possible violation of securities law and regulatory disclosures by the Adani group. The court initially wanted it done by May 2.

SEBI is investigating alleged breach of related-party transaction rules, public shareholding norms and share price manipulation.

Related-party transaction rules lay down practices to be followed when a listed company is involved in a transaction with another party, while public shareholding norms set out the minimum shareholding of a listed company required to be held by the public.

Beside flagship Adani Enterprises (ADEL.NS) , other group companies include edible oils business Adani Wilmar (ADAW.NS) , Adani Ports (APSE.NS) , Adani Green Energy (ADNA.NS) , Adani Transmission (ADAI.NS) , Adani Total Gas (ADAG.NS) , Adani Power (ADAN.NS) , broadcaster NDTV (NDTV.NS) and cement units ACC Ltd (ACC.NS) and Ambuja Cements (ABUJ.NS) .

The panel said, citing SEBI, there was evidence of a build-up in short positions on Adani group stocks ahead of the Hindenburg report.

It was not possible to conclude whether there had been regulatory failures regarding price manipulations, the panel said in the report.

Ukraine said on Friday Russian forces were trying to recapture land they had lost around the devastated eastern Ukrainian city of Bakhmut, but that Ukrainian troops were repelling the attacks.

Deputy Ukrainian Defence Minister Hanna Maliar said the Russian forces had gained some ground inside Bakhmut itself in fierce fighting but did not control the city.

"The enemy is trying to regain what they have lost... but our forces are repulsing the attacks," she said in televised remarks. "It's very difficult to carry out combat missions there and every metre (of advance) is like 10 kilometres in other conditions."

She said the Russian forces had made "some progress" inside Bakhmut but did not say how far forward they had advanced.

The head of Russian mercenaries fighting in Bakhmut said the city was unlikely to fall in the next two days. Ukrainian soldiers, he said, were holed up in a makeshift "fortress" in the south of the city.

Moscow regards its assault on Bakhmut, a city of about 70,000 before Russia's full-scale invasion nearly 15 months ago, as an important part of a campaign to capture the rest of the industrial Donbas region of eastern Ukraine.
